div.p: As it was Acted, with great Applause, by their Majesties Servants at the private House in Drury Lane.
LONDON, Printed for Will: Sheares, at the Bible in S. Pauls Churchyard, neare the little North doore, 1654.

list.item: Valentia, Daughter to the Mantuan Duke.

div.head: ACT I. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: MAturity and age have now at length
imposed on me a carefull providence
Both for my Dukedoms safety, & the good
Of our most hopefull Son Prince Prospero.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: You grow to ripenesse, and my thoughts are fix'd
To have you troth-plight to some noble wife,
That in my aged yeares I may have comfort
In your faire issue, I would have you marry.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Marry my Lord!

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I, marry Prospero.
I have labour'd with a neighbour Prince, possest
Of a faire Daughter, to confirme a match
'Twixt thee and her, and 'tis concluded firmly;
Her name Valentia, she his only child,
By which a setled League grows 'twixt our Dukedomes,
And thou by this art the true hopefull Heire
Of both out rich and wealthy Provinces:
Your answer.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: I am free, my Lord, as th' uncurb'd aire,
That comes not within limit, as the light
That nothing can imprison. Shall I truly
Speake my own thoughts, and not dissemble with you?
I that am free 'mongst men, and uncaptiv'd
To any, save the duty bound to you,
Am loath to make my selfe a womans slave,
Briefely, my Lord, I have no mind to marry.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Not marry boy? Oh, knew'st thou what a sweetnesse
And harmonie's in loves blest fellowship
Thou wouldst embrace it gladly; this blest union,
This true-loves knot the Gods themselves do tye,
And none but death dissolves. And what's Virginity?
A something-nothing, singularity
Unsociable, so slightly reckon'd of
That either Sex, but to thy number grown,
Has a desire to leave it; be perswaded boy;
Thou hast beheld the Picture, and it promises
A perfect Lady; hadst thou seen the substance
Thou wouldst condemne the workman for so scanting
Her rare comparelesse beauty. Marriage,
Why 'tis an honour, Emperours, Kings, and Princes,
From the Pallace to the Cottage held it sacred
And in a high religious reverence.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Well, my Lord, I will be steer'd by you;
Even through the turbulent Ocean of this life,
Where many dreadfull tempests threaten us,
I shall be swai'd by you, and entertaine
This sweet captivity,

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Then art thou wise— the news. Flourish.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Embassadours from Mantua crave admittance
Touching affaires of state.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Admit 'em— Enter Embassadours.
Lords, your arrivall is in happy season;
The marriage so long treated 'tween the Fathers
Shall by the Children be confirmed at length,
'Tis now on foot.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Your grace mistakes the tenour,
And the strange purpose our Embasie;
The Prince our Master lets know by us
That your alliance highly he disdaines,
Contemnes your love and neere affinity,
And for just reasons, to himselfe best known,
Desires your opposition; for the marriage
Treated between you, esteemes his Daughter
Much undervalued, and not rated truly
To her best worth.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Pause Lord Embassadour,
So high hath thy words incens'd our spleene,
And set so just an edge upon our wrath
That we want patience to bestow an care
Unto thy harsh conclusion: Tell thy Lord,
We did not so much over-prize his love
As here his hate held in the basest scorne;
Nor can he so much undervalue us
As we his Contracts and Confederacy;
And for thy self-presumptuous Mantuan Lord,
We favour thee to let thee undisgrac'd
Depart our Court, be gone without reply,
Not Mantuans, but Mantua we defie.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: Let me conclude my Message.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Convey him hence;
Disdaine our fellowship! Mantua shall know
His state shall lessen whilst our glories grow.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: I, but, my Lord, I hope the match is not broke off
Betweene me and the faire Valentia.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Oh boy, didst thou but know what marriage were,
How full of troubles and contentions,
Thou wouldst forgo it gladly; who that's free
Would be confin'd to base Effeminacy?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: But that which hath made in me the deepest impression
Is the rare Picture of the Lady Valentia.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: The Painter flattered her, in having her
Thou hast a painted Mistris, of her selfe
The Lady is mishapen and deformed.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Nay, take me with you, my Lord,
I have beheld her Picture, and it promises
A perfect Lady; had I seen the substance
I should condemne the workman for so scanting
Her rare comparelesse beauty; these were your own words,
My Lord, or I much misunderstood them.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: They were indeed, my Lord, I am witnesse to them.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Well since your Grace has no purpose to have me marry,
Shall I have your best furtherance to travell?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Yes, any thing to weare out the remembrance
Of Mantuas Daughter.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Another boone, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: What's that Coz?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: That I may be his Partner in his travell, his associate
To beare him company, nothing else my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Have your desires.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: I embrace your fellowship,
Ile travell, but whither? to have a sight of the faire Valentia,
There shall be the period of my Voyage;
What though her Father and mine be opposites, she and I
May happily agree well enough when we meet together.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: My Lord, what limit shall we have to play the wandring Knights in? Or how long shall it be ere we set forward on our Journey? We were best go well provided, for we must see Spaine, France, and England ere we returne.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Some ten daies hence you shall set forward,
Your stay hath a yeares limit.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Then come, faire Coz, we must provide our selves;
Her Picture's lovely, and it much contents,
And I must see the face that it presents. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Your youths cannot outstrip my gravity,
I have you boyes, and aime at your intents;
This cunning suit for travell is a colour
To some close practice to deceive my age,
But I shall wind them both, Cosmo.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: The mannage of our State we leave to thee,
Whom we know wise and gravely provident;
Our purpose is to chase these travellers,
Whose voyage we mistrust.

sp.speaker: Coz.
sp.l: 'Tis dangerous
Unto your noble person, full of hazard
And doubtfull perill.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I am confident,
Disswade me not, for my intent is fixt;
In some suspectlesse shape Ile after them,
And sound the inmost of their thoughts, yet passe unknown;
Cosmo regard your charge whilst I provide. Flourish.
To find that craft they with such cunning hide. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: You have breath'd defiance then.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: I have my Lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And how did he receive it?

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: With such scorne
And proud contempt, that with far greater spleene
He threatned us than we could menace him.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: No matter, this late difference pleaseth us,
You have demean'd your selfe even to our wish,
Now leave us to our private meditations. Exeunt. Em.
Come hither Sirra, I repose in thee
Much trust and much assured confidence,
I have brought thee up of a youth boy, I have.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: You have if it shall please your Grace.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Thy Father was a good old servitour,
I lov'd him well, I did, indeed I did,
Beleeve it, for I did so.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I beleeve your Lordship without swearing.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Thou knowst my Daughter should have been affied
Unto Verona's Son Prince Prospero,
I know thou knowst it.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: I have had, if it please your Grace, such an inckling,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: But a difference since
Hath falne betwixt us, nay, in such a manner
That by our Leagers we have threatned war,
And war is like to ensue to come to thee.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: If it shall please your honour, Ile save you that labour and come to you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Conceive me, I will come to that concerns thee,
Thou knowst how deerly I affect my Daughter,
I, and how deerely I affect my Gold,
Speake, did I ever yet part with one peece
To guerdon thee, a signe I lov'd it well.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: No, never, if it shall please your honour, Ile do you right in that, you ever lov'd me too well to give me any thing, I have ever heard you reported for as covetous and niggardly a noble Gentleman as ever bore sway here, you are one of the most closse-fisted Carpenters that ever bare rule in Mantua.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: To keep my Daughter that she marry not,
By which I like wise may reserve her dower,
I have devis'd this opposition
'T weene Valentia and Prince Prospero;
More Sutors are now resident in Court,
But to prevent them Ile devise a Tower
In which to shut my Daughter so impregnable
And full of dores, of which Ile keep the keyes,
That she in vaine shall strive to issue out,
Or they to enter in; this strong foundation
Is laid already, workmen are employ'd,
And all things promise prosperous successe;
In this employment thou shalt have a charge,
An overseers place, because I know thee
Simple but sure of faith: wee i trust thy reach,
As far from craft as cunning, truly honest
Because not over wise.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I must entreate your Lordship I may have a paire of Chopeens, or some high Cork'd shooes, or else I shall never
play the overseer well; or if your Lordship will allow me but a Ladder, I warrant you I will oversee your workmen.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: No more, there shall be order from our Treasury
To furnish this rich building—

div.stage: Enter Florence, Ferrara, Julio, Valentia, and Dutchesse.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Our welcome would shew better,
If we could heare it from the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: They come well that speed well, if we could find our selves well sped, then we should not doubt to presume we were well-come.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Lord Julio, are the toyles prepar'd and set for our appointed game.?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: They are my Lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Then Princes we devote this day to pastime
And chasing of the Stag, these beauteous Ladies,
That must this day take leave of liberty,
Shall in our sport associate us; Valentia,
And you most beauteous, and my dearest Love,
I here protest my selfe your Guardian,
Hoping to see you, ere two months expire,
The Mantuan Dutchesse.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I hope no such matter; but my Lord,
Am I your Deare, as you proclaime me?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: My dearest Deare.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Then being in the chase I shall feare in the hunting:
To come neare you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Your reason Sweet.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Lest being your Deare you should strike me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Still is this Lady crosse to my designes,
But time may worke her; Daughter, mount your Steed,
And Lords to horse, the morning grows upon us,
And steales towards midst of day.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We but attend
Your Highnesse company.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Lady, this day I will not start from your side.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You'l be worse to me than a stitch then.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Nor will I leave you Lady,

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: And yet you shall have free leave to leave me when you please.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: We trifle houres, found out your bugles sh
And the thick aire with pleasing ecchoes fill. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: To ring thy knell, for this day thou art doom'd
To perish by the hand of Iulio— Hornes.
The Mantuan Prince
Is now upon the Chace, I heare the cry,
But ere the stagg fall the proud Duke must dye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Harke what a shrill applause doth welcome us
Unto the Mantuan Confines.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: It seemes the Duke or some of his traine
Are in the Forrest chacing some game;
Nay, it must needs be so of necessity, they would not else make
This noyse unlesse they were all horne-mad.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: If I should come a wooing, noble Coz,
I should presage the Musick of these hornes
Might, to my future match, prove ominous;
But now let's mixe our selves amidst the Traine,
And see what faire adventure may befall us.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Sever our selves, it may be that sweet face
Your Father prais'd may meet us in the Chace.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: I like well this division, come let's part,
And let's be henceforth strangers, thus condition'd,
The first that can prefer himselfe, or service
Unto the Duke, or gaine his soveraigne grace
Shall for his friend provide some eminent place.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I am pleas'd my Lord, then come let's mount away,
The morning's old, and we shall lose much day. Exeunt. (Horns.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: With these Italian tricks villaines oft maske
Their grim bloud-thirsty fronts, and when they purpose
To act some horrid murder, if prevented,
Thus passe unknown, these bought I of a Jew,
A fellow that professeth villaine;
Ile dog the Duke, whom if I can but single,
Or light on from his Traine, but thus, 'tis done,
The Dukedome seiz'd, and faire Valentia wonne;
Auspicious hell I thank: thee, thou art still
True to black deeds, and friend to such as kill—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: My horse hath fail'd me, and I forc'd on foot
To lag behind, my Traine have left me all,
Led by the musick of so faire a Cry,

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: To find a place where thou maiest fitly dye.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Who named death to me?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: One whose powerfull hand
Shall guide thy Dukedome, Daughter, and thy Land,
And at one blow gaine all—

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: And we so nigh,
The slave that threatned death himselfe shall dye.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Prevented. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Courage, my Lord, the traiterous groome is fled,
And you ingirt with safety.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Noble stranger,
The life thou hast given me shall be ever thine,
And thanke the stars that brought thee to my rescue,
They ow'd thee a great fortune, thou hast sav'd
The Mantuan Duke from death.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Are you my Lord,
The noble Mantuan Prince? what Traitours hand
Durst threat your life?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I know not, gentle sir,
But for your selfe thus much presume from me,
You shall be ever ours, to none more deare,
By whom I am freed from treason, death and feare.

div.stage: Enter Iulie, Florende, Ferrara, Valentia, Dutchesse, and Montecelso.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: This way, my Lords, I saw the Duke in perills
An ugly slave, his face much Vizard-like.
Assail'd the Duke, and with his weapon drawn
Fled through the Forest, I pursu'd the Traitour
Whilest I had breath, but fears and guilt of conscience
Gave his speed wings; but see my Lord's in safety,
Whose welfare I salute thus on my knee,
Glad in my soule that he from death is free.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My Father threatned I blest be that faire hand
That wrought his safety.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Thanke this Gentleman,
This noble youth, 'tis he by whom I live,
Never so neare my death, never so neare it,
So mortall men are still when least they feare it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Oh do but tell me, thrice renowned sir,
How I may shew me thankfull to your love,
Whose noble hand preserv'd my fathers life.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Madam, your grace, your favour and good thoughts
Are gifts above my merit.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Stranger, thou hast wonne the opinion and suffrage of the whole Court, and bound the Prince of Florence to be thy gratefull debtor.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: We made hast
To the Dukes rescue, but it was thy fate
Our valours to prevent, we came too late.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Yet did Lord Iulio, with what speed he might, haste us to this great danger.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: 'Twas my duty
And service to my Lord, whom thus to see
Secur'd from death glads, almost frantiques me;
Legs for my life I thanke, and thou my braine
For making up this broken flaw againe.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: We thanke you Iulio, chiefely you faire stranger,
Whom for your service we will raise in Court,
And breast next our most deare Valentia;
But she is for the Tower bar'd with twelve doores,
And this the last day of her liberty,
That's our next businesse; once more welcome sir,
Attend on us to Court, our happy fate
Hath given me safety, and advanc'd thy state. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Oh faire Valentia!

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: My Lord, if you had been born lesse than a Prince, yet you have wrought your selfe into grace.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Here set a period to our travels, make a full point here.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: And that, my Lord, is the full end of a sentence; but shall we give over travell till we have seen something worth seeing.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Worth seeing sai'st thou? what's Valentia?
Travell from Pole to Pole, stand at the Center
And progresse round about the spatious signes,
Or, were it possible, sit with the Sun
In his high noon-tide glory, and from thence
Survey the Kingdomes of this lower world,
Thou canst not find her match, Apollo's haire
Is dull to hers, her fingers, hand, eye, front.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Take me with you my Lord: This marvellous thing you call her beauty, is it ought but ordinary flesh and bloud? Are those gold wiry haires with which Apollo might go string his Harpe, are they ought but the plaine haires of her head? Her Ivory palme, that doth in touching melt, embroidered with blew artires, is it ought but a Ladies hand and fingers? And this strange thing, this wonder of the world, whose peere cannot be found betweene the Poles, are not all these nine wonders in one, she that was here even now, the Dukes Daughter Valentia?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Oh my deare Montecelso, this I know,
But such an admiration hath surpriz'd
The freedome of my senses, that it robs me
Of my true judgement.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Be advis'd by me: you love this Lady, but so strict is like to be her imprisonment, that you may as easily pass by the gates that Cerberus keeps, as through the doores of this Castle; you are already in favour with the Duke, do but preferre me to be overseer of the worke, if I do not worke it so that I will bring you to oversee her, turne me out of my office as one not worthy the name of an Architecture.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p:
I shall commend thee for a man well skill'd a such great structures, it may be the Duke
May trust me on my word.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: And if I do not make him dote as much on you for your valour, as you make him enamour'd on me for my skill in building, may this Tower turne to the Tower of Babel, and make a second confusion betweene us, there remaines for you nothing but this, to winne the favour of the Lady; and for your accesse to her, if I do not teach you to counterfeit all the Dukes keyes, turne by all the wards of his locks & lay open all the Jurie of his twelve doores that he hath pannell'd against your entrance, report me to be no man of my trade: Away my Lord, leave this melancholly, walke by her window, and cast sheeps eyes that way towards her Chamber, let me alone to stand Centinell and watch if the Duke come. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Clowne, a Smith, a Mason, a Bricklayer, a Carpenter.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Come on my masters, the Duke has appointed me to be Overseer of his workes, the building of this Tower is put to my indiscretion; therefore come every one of you, and from me take your directions; what are you?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I am a free Mason, and expert in squaring stone.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: A good proper square fellow, if your trade be in stone,
I make no question but you will worke hard.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: I warrant you sir Ile do my endeavour; will you give us directions?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: First you must make a faire large post at the entrie.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: I warrant you Ile make a large porch that any Lady shall go in and out at pleasure.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: To see how you mistake; you must make it that no body can go in and out at pleasure but only my Ladie, it must be too wide for any that's lesse than shee, and too strait for any that's greater than she, you conceive me.
sp.l: Oh sir, 'tis not possible.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Tell not me of possible, such directions I had, and such an one I must have made: Then must I have faire bay windows that must alwaies stand open and give no light, that they that stand without and looke in may see no body within, and she that stands within and looks out may see no body without; the
reason is, my Lord meanes to keep his daughter in that Tower, where she must neither see nor be seen.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Then none must offer to looke out from the inside, nor in from the outside, else 'tis not within the compasse of workmanship.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Tell not me of workmanship, such windows I must have made: Now Carpenter for you, you must make the doores of that fashion that women may go in but men may not, and they must be of such wood as will not let a Lover come neare it, for my Lord will have no Lovers come neare his Castle.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Then you must have some body to keep them out; here are wise directions!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: For you goodman Padlock, you must hammer out your Locks and Keyes with such Art, that if the Duke, or any from him, offer to open, the Key may turne at pleasure, but if any Lover or suspitious person come to enter, Nonsum, non possum, non Licet esse Domi.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: That's as much as to say, they must have no entrance there.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Smith, you have hit the naile on the head; What's your place?

sp.speaker: Brick.
sp.p: I have the charge of the brick-worke, and must build the Chimnies if you would give me directions.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Marry will I sir, you must have a speciall regard in your Chimneys that they cast heat, though there be no fire in them, and the Kitchin Chimney especially must every meale yeeld rost meat without sending to market, and so to worke for a spurt, and after merrily to dinner.

sp.speaker: Omues.
sp.l: A good motion. Exeunt.

div.head: ACT II. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Mantua, Florence, Ferrara, Iulio, and Prospero.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: HAve you given charge, Lord Iulio, that my Dutchess
Be nobly serv'd as her whom Mantua loves?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I have my Lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And that Valentia be inclos'd and shut
From all her sutors eies.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I gave such order.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Enough now my Lords.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You give us faire words; but keep us from the sight of the faire Ladies.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Soft and faire, soft and faire.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: We know they are both soft and faire, and that's the reason we desire so much both to see and feele them.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I would beneath the ground sels of this Castle,
By Miners craft, were plac'd some strong Petars,
To which I would give fire and blow this structure
Up into aire that prisons thus my Love;
But Iulio peace, and some advantage wait
To shew to her thy love, to him thy hate.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: My Lord, I can compare you to none so rightly as to the King Aerifius, that shut up his Daughter Danae in a brazen Tower, but you know the end of it, there was a Jupiter that with a golden pick-lock broke through those brazen gates, and made the maid a mother. Now if
sp.l: I were to choose a godhead, of all the gods that are
Would I, for her sake, wish to be a Jupiter.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: For men to be made gods it were a wonder,
You Iove, and neither have his power nor thunder?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Shall I baile her my Lord? Ile put you in good security.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: But not in better security than I have put her in already,
Yet better would do well; oh for a man
Skilfull in Architecture, and composing
Strong frames and formes of building.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Now's my question;
My Lord, there is a stranger in your Court
Whose outside though it promise not much Art,
Yet is he so ingenious, and so apt,
Of such opinion and direction too,
That could you win him to be so imploy'd,
As we shall hardly, for men excellent
Are curious of their skill, you cannot find
A man to match his skill in Italy.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Thou wert I see, faire Knight, mark'd in thy Cradle
To do me all good offices, bring that man
To my employment, I will guerdon him
With more than he can aske.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I, but my Lord,
He is a man alwaies so absolute,
And stands so much upon his excellence
In fine contriving and rare edifices
We shall have much adoe to win him to't— Ent. Mont.
Here comes the man.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Sir, your due praise hath, like a harbinger,
Gone all the way before you to provide you
A place in my regard, you are most welcome,
You have not seen my Castle?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Yes my Lord, I have perus'd it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What thinke you of the worke?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: 'Tis pretty, pretty;
'Tis well for moderne builders, homebred workmen,
'Twill serve: Yet let me tell you, worthy Lord,
They never look'd on high Mauselus Tombe,
Never beheld a Grecian Pyramis,
Rich Crassus house at Rome, Diana's Temple
At Ephesus, nor the grand City Caire,
'Tis well for them that are no travellers;
Saw you me draw a forme, or a fine modell,
The Fabrick greatly would enamour you,
But yet 'tis well enough, pretty, not famous,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Shall I entreat you to direct my workmen,
And I will weigh your paines down with reward.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Your Tower as 'tis, my Lord, will serve the turne,
Is finely seated, and to keepe your Daughter
Close from the eyes of strangers, well contriv'd,
Yet could I by a plot, but why should I
Engage me in such worke? 'tis well already,
Well, very well.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: You can contrive it better, noble stranger;
Make triall of my bounty, by mine honour
It shall not faile your hopes.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Did not I tell you at the first, my Lord,
He would be wondrous dainty of his cunning?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: So most men are in things they best excell;
Shall I prevaile faire sir?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Well, I am wonne
To end that frame your workmen have begun;
I have perus'd the scituation,
Find it secure and full of able trust,
Yet one defect I find: Could you pick out
Some noble Knight, whose valour did exceed,
To build for him a Lodging neare that Tower
Where faire Valentia is to live enclos'd,
He, as a Guardian, or a Centinell,
Might keep continuall watch, defend the passage,
And keepe the place strong and impregnable?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Where should I find a man worthy that place,
Whose valour might supply this my employment?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Let me engage my person to that businesse.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Accept of me my Lord, Ile be her Guardian.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Let the Ferrara Marquess be employ'd
In this adventure.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: List to me my Lord:
'Mongst other quests, once as I travell'd Greece,
There, at the sack of a most famous towne,
I saw a Knight, now resident in Court,
Do such high deeds of Armes, that living Hector,
Had he surviv'd to see his Chivalry,
Would from the Worthies nine have rais'd his name,
To have eterniz'd him with golden fame.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: In our Court resident?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Yes, that strange Knight,
What wonders have I seen him do in fight!
Would he attempt it, all the plot were sure,
Your Selfe, your Daughter, and your Tower secure;
But you shall hardly win him to attempt.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: That he is valiant I must needs confesse
To my lives safeguard I have prov'd no lesse;
Oh every way my friend; renowned Souldier,
Pardon me that I have not done you honours
Worthy your high deserts.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Alas my Lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: My cares are deafe unto excuse, and shut
Gainst all deniall.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I am exceeding loath.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I shall deserve it, noble Gentleman,
I must not be deni'd, this skilfull stranger
Shall cause my workmen build you a faire Lodging
Next to the Castle, and adjoyning close
Unto my Daughters Chamber: this is all;
Can you deny me this?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Your former honours
Bestow'd so largely on my meane deserts
Have been with me prevailing Oratours
Upon your part, and I at length agree
This skilfull Artist shall dispose of me.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Againe prevented.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: On all sides happy, fortunate, and blest,
Now my disturb'd thoughts attaine true rest,
Only one bar unto my best desires
Is the intire affection and true zeale
I beare the beautious Dutchesse.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Oh my Lord,
You have entertain'd the most affecting wooer
In Europe, or the world, therein he's better
Than in his Architecture, he's but young,
Yet Tully ne're had such a fluent tongue.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Hem'd in with all felicities about,
Having these helps what need I now misdoubt?
You shall sir beare from me most kind commends.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Who, I my Lord? Alas.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Come sir, you shall
Unto the beauteous Dutchesse whom I love.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: You do not know my weaknesse.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: You are strong
In your acute words, and prais'd for your sweet tongue,
A token I will send by you, that give her,
And in your own sweet words my love deliver.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: If need's Ile do't my Lord: upon my life
The provident Duke has found me out a wife.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Follow us Lords, I am full of jocund mirth,
My feares are dead, my joyes receive new birth. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Now Prince, was not this wrought out of Adamant?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: But what's the marke that all the severall arrows shoot at?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: This is the marke, marke it, I am made chiefe overseer of the worke, and your Lodging is directly against the Chamber of the Lady: Now will I appoint a private doore to be made through the wall, by and through which you may have accesse, ingresse and regresse at your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Thou hast builded in my heart a Tower already
Of steady and firme hope.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Take my word I am excellent at Architecture.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: But touching thy employment with the Dutchesse,
Art thou so mad to wooe her for the Duke?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Yes, I will set him out in his lively colours, deale you as soundly with the maid as I will worke with the widdow, and I doubt not but we shall both live to be in the beliefe there are no Cuekolds but Batchelours, our stay is suspicious, be it your charge to hire—
sp.l: A workman to make the private dore through the wall,
And leave it to my wit to cover all.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: That be my care;
Thou wooest a widdow, but I court a maid,
The way thou tread'st is easie, broad, and free,
But mine is strait, and danger ushers me. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: No marvell though Jove often went disguis'd,
And in his rurall habit trac'd the earth
To heare and see th' affaires of mortall men.
I being a Prince have in these lowly weeds
Seen more than being resident in Court;
But I am now in Mantua, and thus far
I have pursued my Son by common tract;
The Duke and I are dangerously oppos'd,
And therefore this disguise must shelter me;
The Mantuan Court Ile now search ere I go
For Montecelso and my princely Son—

div.stage: Enter Clown with a rule and line.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Let me see, let me see, make a doore so broad, I, so broad, and thus wide; now unlesse I had the Lady here to take measure of her 'tis impossible that ever I should make the doore fit; if a man take a thing in hand, it is for his credit to do it workeman like; now if I should make the doore too streight to pinch her body, or too wide to sit upon her like a sack, what credit should I have by my workmanship?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Heaven save you sir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Et tu quoque my friend; let me see, let me see, now have I forgotten whether the doore must be made for her to come thus, with her armes broad waies, Pilcher-fashion, and a kembo; or thus side-waies, like a shotten herring.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Sir, without interruption to your businesse, shall I entreat a few words with you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Hold here, hold here a little, thus high, I, thus high, just thus high; but now my friend, if I should make it just thus high according to my measure, and then the party being yet but young should grow higher, there were all the labour cast away; come, come, I must have a new measure.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Sir, what means this? I understand it not,
Pray let me aske you but one question.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Hold againe, hold againe, say my friend I make it of this breadth according to my measure, just to a haire; very good my
friend, but now the party being yet but leane that it should be made for, say the party hereafter grow fat, or as the Fox that when his belly was empty crept through a small hole into a hen-roost, and there fill'd his belly so full, that when he should come out againe, there was no roome; Colon was grown so great, and so poore Reynald was taken in the manner, no, my friend, this must not be.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I pray sir to what end take you this measure?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Why, my friend, because I would do nothing out of measure, I hope you have not plaid the old eavesdropper.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: No sir, but if your chiefe affaires be ended,
Let me discourse with you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: My friend, as you have lent a hand to my Line, so will I lend an care to your tale.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: What's the best news in Court?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Troth sir nothing but this, that the Prince is magnanimous, the Courtiers egregious, the Ladies beautious, the place conspicuous, and the building in hand most sumptuous.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: What strangers so journe there, what men of note?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Troth sir there are only two, one is most brave at models and buildings, and hath undertaken a most brave peece of worke.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: That's not my Son, he never studied that,
No, not his friend.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: But there is another, the finest sweet-fac'd Gentleman, that sav'd the Dukes life in the Forrest, if you know not that you know nothing, if you know not him you know no body.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: What manner of man is he?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: A most dainty man, much of my size, he hath a most leering lip and tempting eye, there is only this difference between us, for you would take us to be brothers, but that he has more haire than I, and I more wit than he; Father, you are not worthy to be held a good Subject, if you love not him that had like to have kill'd him that would have kill'd the Duke, he hath set me about this peece of work here, let me see, this block-head of mine will never bring it to any purpose— Ent. Prosp. Oh here comes the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: He interpose himselfe and save the Duke!
That looke, that face, that gesture is my Sons.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Oh well incounter'd, tell me honest fellow,
Hast thou dispatch'd the close and secret doore?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Not yet my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: What dost thou with that Line?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I am staying here, that if she should come down this way,
I may take measure of her to make the doore fit for her body.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Away you asse, thou wilt betray my purpose;
But sirrah on your life use seeresie,
And with all speed dispatch it; but what's he?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: A Fellow that wonders so young a Gentleman as your selfe should take the Dukes quarrell in hand, and save him from the sword of a Traitour.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: 'Tis Prospero my Son, shape, gate, and voice,
To heare his valour prais'd how I rejoice,

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: This fellow at a blush looks like my Father,
Such setled gravity lives in his eye;
Nor is there wanting ought save power and state,
Attended with the royall name of Duke
To make him the same man; but I digresse;
Come to your private taske, sirrah be secret,
Or thy life paies for't.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I warrant you sir, I would be as loath to hazzard my neck as you the Dukes favour, his favour once lost may be got again, but my neck once broke, Ile not trust all the bone-setters in Mantua to have it new set; feare not me.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: This aged man is still tost in my thoughts,
And ever as I cast a look on him,
His face grows more familiar with my eye;
But to our taske in hand, why do we stay?
His cloath of state cannot be turn'd to gray. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Is this your travell Son? Oh heaven to see
The follies and the vaine delights of youth,
How headstrong, and how full of violence!
Why should he take this way? why sojourne here
Within my enemies Court? If to revenge
My Injuries, why did he rescue him?
Oh mine own Boy!
I must commend thee yet that could'st win love
Even of thy enemies, and honour'd fame
'Mongst those, that if they knew thee, hate thy name;
Ile listen further till some fate bewray
The full intent of his enforced stay. Exit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: My Daughter is securely clos'd and shut
In my new Turret, and the noble Knight,
As her bold guardian, hath his place assign'd,
Those feares have end; now to my sute in hand,
The stranger whom so late I entertain'd
Is my sollicitor, and is directed
To meet and court the Dutchesse in the garden,
Where from this place I may behold their gestures,
The manner of his courtship and conceit:
How is my heart disturb'd 'tween hope and feare—
Comfort cold spirit, they now methinks appeare.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: The greatest instance of my love is, that I have given into your hands my liberty and life; my name is Montecelso, and that noble Gentleman that rescued the Duke Prince Prospero, Son to the Duke of Verona, it lies in you either to save me alone, or to destroy us both; give me no deniall, sweet Lady, rather kill me than disclose me to the Duke, so shall you lessen the supposition of your cruelty.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: In that you are a stranger, I can no lesse in courtesie, nor more in modesty than to say you are welcome, though I have been trusted by many, I never betrayed any; I could call you rash to trust so rich a Jewel as your life unto the brest of a woman, but though you be so over-bold to presume upon me, I will not prove so over cruell to tyrannize over you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: She talk'd a great long tale, and loud she spake,
sp.l: To her again, do not that answer take.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Madam, by all the honours of a Gentleman, my love is as pure to you, and as free from blemish as is the element of fire, or the white robe of Innocence.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I know it is, I know it is.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p:
All the comfort I can give you is this, the life you
have committed to me shall be kept for you, the love you have proffered to me I will ponder on, I will never marry till you are bestow'd, nor ever assume the name of wife till you meet with a Lady to call you husband.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Give me your hand of that.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: I may well trust you with my hand that have trusted me with your heart.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: A match I hope, for see, they now joine hands,
My heart for joy upon the tiptoe stands;
Follow it now, strike whilst the Iron's hot,
I ne're was pleas'd till now with a fine plot.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: But you forget in all this to speake for the Duke.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Madam, 'tis true, I did forget my selfe, I must entreat you to thinke of him, but I do not entreat you to thinke well of him, as ill as you can possible; I beseech you love to be out of his sight in any case, and to love him best when he is farthest off: I would have you in all humility to honour him, but I would not for a world have you to marry him; have I yet spoke for him sufficiently?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Good, good, well spoken, and well acted too,
He is not halfe so good to plot as wooe.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: My Lord, the love we now celebrate betwixt our selves should once have been solemnized between our parents, before these odds grew between the two Dukes.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Though the Dukes be at odds, let us make even,
Contracts are made on earth, but seal'd in heaven;
Madam, let the Dukes love be the colour to our meeting: I must go tell him the manner, for with much longing he expects my returne.
Once more let these our hands our hearts make sure,
So thrive I as my love is chaste and pure. Exit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Againe, againe, faire fortune be thy speed,
Once more joine hands, and then 'tis done indeed;
I knew the good Knight would not choose a man
That should not fit my purpose, heaven I pray.
His place may take effect the other way,
And his intents as prosperously proceed;
But I must hence to meet him with all speed. Exit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You wrong mine honour, and I shall complaine,
I charge you get you back the way you came.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Banish the heaven if you exile me hence;
My deed, though it seeme rash, yet is begot
In as pure birth as truth, and as upright
As is the scale of Justice; I am free
From all mis-thoughts, then do not banish me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What are you sir? whence are you? what's your name?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I am your friend, should you desire to know
What my name is, alas my name's your foe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Being my friend, and court me in this kind
You should have come and left your name behind.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I should indeed, my name is Prospero.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Prince Prospero, and the Duke Verona's Son, Our profest Foe?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Give me some other name,
Call me your friend and I am not the same.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Y'are not the same, you are th' advent'rous Knight
That from the forrest-treason sav'd my Father.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I was Prince Prospero when I resen'd him,
And so continued till I saw your face;
But as my heart within your eye was tost,
At once my hatred and my name I lost.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It was a kind foes part to save a foe.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: That kind foes part perform'd Prince Prospero

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Such a faire foe that no more hurt intends
I should prefer before a many friends.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Lady, we should have been espous'd together,
But that our Fathers differ'd in the Dower;
Shall Gold divorce them whom the soule of love
Links in an endlesse knot? I for your love
First hazarded my life to come disguis'd
Only to view your face, next I contriv'd
This private passage, known to none but us;
If this deserve no love, no friendlie grace,
Confine my life if banish me this place.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: If nothing but the rescue of my Father
Should plead in your behalfe; it deserv'd favour;
But when your travell, and your servent love,
Attended with year feature and rare parts,
Your studious meanes to compasse my consent
And hazzard of your fortunes many waies,
When all these plead together forciblie
They draw me in a treble folded chaine
Your zealous love to pay with love againe.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I left my name behind me at Verona,
And now no more Prince Prospero but your Love;
Weare this for me, and use in these affaires
My art, feare not, I will devise a meanes
To win your Fathers grant unto this match.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: So we, my Lord, shall doubly be made friends,
I take it as an earnest of your love,
And hope of my release from this strict bondage;
Accept of me in interchange this Ring,
My Father gave it me, keep't from his eye,
Or he will end our loves by jealousie—

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: As I have been, I will be firme and sure,
Long may the date of our chaste love endure—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I prethee, sweet Marquesse, since my successe is so bad with the Dutchesse let's walke by the Dukes new edifice, and see if we can take a view of the young inclosed Lady.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Content my Lord, the Dukes strictnesse adds but spurs to my desire; for commonly what we are most forbid that still we most covet.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Then should you with some engine raze these walls
That interdicts your passage to that Tower;
Had I such power I should enjoy such thoughts,
But Iulio is a Subject.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Now you put me in mind of such generous and noble thoughts, let's take a view of the Castle, and spy where it is weakest, that there, if hereafter we should invade, we may give the best and safest assault.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Now you speake like a politicks Lover, come lets take a view of the building: But see, see, do you know him that's
talking with the Princesse Valentia?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Is't possible, Ile in and tell the Duke.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Nay, leave me not behind, Ile second you.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Introth Lad art good at that? you are a notable rascall, can you come to't
So closely? is this your courage my couragious Knight?
Ile see how Mantua applauds this fight. Exit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We are descry'd my Lord, then post away,
Get through the private doore.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Feare not sweet Lady, Ile so blind their eyes,
That we will still live free from their surprise. Exit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ten thousand times adieu, I am full of feare;
Where love inhabits danger still draws neare. Ex.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ALL is too good to be true, but tell me,
And answer every word upon thy oath.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Upon my oath I will.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Then tell me, tell me,
Didst thou with all thy best prevailing words,
With all thy art, with all thy eloquence
Urge her to love? speake that upon thy oath.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Upon my oath I did entreat her love:
With all my art, with all my eloquence.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And did she grant thy sute?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: She did my Lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Thou honest man, thrice happy be the houre
That I first met thee; now upon thy life
Tell me how speed'st thou?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Well upon my life.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And will she love?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: She will.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Thou hast her promise

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I have my Lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: But hast thou, as thou art a Gentleman

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: As I am a Gentleman I have my Lord,
I should be sorry else.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Did thy word prosper, took thy sute effect?
Will she be wonne to marry at thy motion?
And did she give her hand unto the bargaine.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: My sute and words were both effectuall,
She's wonne to marry, and I have her hand
As witnesse to the bargaine.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Friend, sweare that.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Upon my life, my Lord, it is most true.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'Tis well, I thanke my stars.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I thanke my stars too.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I thanke thee too, but for thy industry
This thing had never chanc'd.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Nay, that's most certaine,
Had I not took my time and ply'd it throughly,
I had never wonne her heart.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: But thou hast wonne it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I, I thanke heaven my Lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And I thanke heaven my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: She hath past her word and her firme promise to me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: It glads me at the heart, the very heart.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Nor have I reason to be sorry for it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Once more I thanke thee friend.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: 'Tis not so much worth my Lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: That be my perill, Ile 'bide the venture.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: You are like to do that howsoever.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: There's gold, gramerey friend, I am thy debter;
This is but th' earnest of those rich rewards
Thou shalt receive from me.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I thanke your grace,
And I protest I would not for a million
My labours had been fruitlesse, trust upon it,
The greatest aime of all my sute is wonne,
Her heart, her hand, her free consent is wonne
To match with me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I thanke my fate 'tis so;
But now about my other businesse friend,
To looke unto my works; blest be the houre
I met thee first, but all is in heavens power. Exit Mon.
An honest and a faithfull Gentleman
Upon my warrant, and I dare relie
Upon his trust and certaine honesty—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: My Lord, you are wrong'd.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Disparag'd.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And disgrac'd.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I bring thee news, thy Castle is surpriz'd,

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Thy Fort is taken.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And your Daughter seiz'd.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: How may that be Lords? 'tis not possible.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I speake no more, my Lord, than what I saw.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What I beheld.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And what these eyes have seen.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: That stranger Knight, in whom thou most affiest.
I saw in a bay window court thy daughter.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Embrace her in his armes, and elaspe her waste.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: She darting smiles at him, and the other.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Nor did they blush, change face, or cease their Courtship, but stood as at the gaze.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Iulie, and Lords,
You make me smile; have you so late perus'd
The scituation, and observ'd the passages,
And can you judge wit or the art of man
Can force accesse there and not use my keys?
Tush, you deceive your selves— Enter Prospero.
Ha ha, ha, come hither Knight and laugh with me
At their three follies, they would needs perswade me
They saw thee court my Daughter in her Chamber,
Where thou didst publikely discourse thy fill,
And yet these keys here at my girdle still.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: They did me the more wrong; I scale your Tower!
It lies not in the reach of humane power.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I know it well, tush, while these keys hang here
Were she faire Danae I not Jove would feare.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: You Tower is stronger the Aerifius hold.
Besides, I am not Jove to raine down gold.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Is't possible my eyes should deceive me!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Sure 'twas he, or the devill in's likenesse.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: There's in this some witchcraft.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: You might as well say that you see this hand
Reaching as high as unto yonder clouds.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I should have seen that Ring upon that hand
Once in my Daughters Chamber; oh my heart
Why dost thou make such traffique with pale feare?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: He hath spy'd the gift, and knows the Ring I weare.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: The same, the same, I will in and see
The issue of my feares, twelve locks, twelve keyes,
And every doore too double-barr'd with Iron,
She in the inmost rome wall'd round about,
It cannot be, and yet the Ring I saw
Urgeth my feares, and forceth me withdraw. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I know your, drift and must your speed prevent,
But I delay; 'tis high time I were gone,
Twelve dores the Duke must passe, and I but one. Exit.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Shall I not trust my eyes?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Though mine should faile me I would witnesse yours.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: It makes me past my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: There's some strange jugling could we find it out;
In all his acts your stranger let us trace,
And if we can, worke him some deepe disgrace. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What hast thou done Valentia, given thy heart
Unto a stranger, and thy Fathers foe?
I wrong the Prince, who with a heart intire
Pursues my spousall love with chaste desire;
This match successefully begun may move
Our Fathers hard hearts to a League of love— Enter. Pro.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Wonder not Madam at my serious haste,
Your Father on my finger spy'd the Ring,
And knowing it, is gone by the known way,
Marke you may heare the doores.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Oh my sweet friend,
Haste through the hidden way, leave it to me
To excuse it, and retort his jealousie.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Adieu sweet Lady,
Harke, harke the last doore.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Deceit hath eyes behind, seems blind before—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What so sad Daughter?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not sad but solitary.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I see no private passage, and my dores
Ranke in their wonted order; prethee Daughter
Shew me the Diamond I gave thee last.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The Ring my Lord?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I the Ring.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why, would your highnesse use it?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: She moves a doubt,
I feare there's guile, and I must find it out.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This is the Ring you meane:

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I, 'tis the same;
Oh my own Girle, fie my suspitious thoughts
That you should lead me to these jealous feares,
But Rings may be alike; my Deare, farewell,
Thou shalt not long in this close prison dwell.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: So Prospero hath promis'd, and Ile rather
Trust him than you, although you be my Father.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I have observ'd sir in your troubled looks
Much discontentment, you seeme in your appearance
To be some man of high and eminent place
With the great Mantuan Duke.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: What's that to thee?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Not much sir, yet out of a generous spirit
In Pilgrims bred, such as I am profest,
I would some cordiall counsels willingly
Bestow upon you, did I know your griefes.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I have in me a naturall melancholly;
I have long aim'd at greatness, but betweene me
And that high point two strangers stand oppos'd;
Canst play the skilfull Surgeon?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Sir I can.
Travell hath taught me much, and though now poore,
Yet in my better daies I have convers'd
In Courts of Princes; would you grace me then
But to prefer my service to the Duke,
I would not doubt but to remove those objects
That so offend your eyes; what are those strangers?

sp.speaker: In.
sp.l: The one a young Knight that professeth Armes:
The other Architecture, both are frequent
In the Dukes eare, and I, that in times past
Had all his bosome and his private thoughts,
Scarce now remember how his Chambers hang,
So seldome's my admittance.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Had you so much interest
In his past favours as to make my tongue
Free to his eare I would remove those flatterers,
And plant you in your first deserved grace;
But might I see these Gallants—

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Here they come;
The one I take to be a Conjurer,
The other his Familiar that he works with,
Ile shew thee reasons for't.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Observe them sir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: 'Tis true my Lord, this night the Dutchess lies in the Castle with the Lady Valentia, 'tis by the Dukes appointment, because she may be a comfortable kind Companion to his Daughter; now this night I have cast it so, that we will be merry with them till past midnight.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: But are the Ladies pleas'd it shall be so?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: The bargain's made and seal'd firme with a kisse,
I set it fast upon the Dutchess lips;
But come let's part till the appointed houre,
We must not be seen too familiar together.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Thou art my better Genius, I agree:
I have no good but what I reape from thee.
Mo. Farewel my Lord, only take heed of eaves-droppers. Ex.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Did you heare that my Lord?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Yes, and it strikes cold unto my heart;
Must they this night meet in Valentia's Tower)
The Devill hath made them picklocks.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Patience sir.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Bid me be frantique, rather raile and curse; at midnight must they meet?
Enough, at that fixt houre Ile rouze the Duke,
And put the Court in uproare, with his Guard
'Siege round the Tower, and take these Incubus
'Midst their lascivious pastimes.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Heare me sir.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I am deafe to counsell, patience, grace and all,
Till in their midnight rapes these strangers fall.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Oh were I now girt with a potent hoste
Of mine owne people, and my selfe in Armes
Engag'd unto his rescue, I could then
Assure me of my noble Son againe;
But I now feare his fall and ominous end,
Whose help bove men to heaven I must commend;
Yet Ile not hence, but note what shall ensue,
Heaven heare my prayers, thou art to just men true.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Madam, this night devote your selfe to mirth, whilst your Father sleeps secure in his Palace, Montecelso hath promis'd to keepe his widdow waking; I assure you Prince Prospero will be here too instantly.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He cannot come unlook'd for, nor unwish'd,
So long as their intents are honourable,
So long their welcome is unquestionable.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Troth Madam we have exceedingly forgot our selves, we should have had a banquet to have entertained them.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Methinkes 'tis better as 'tis without, for the time, that should have been spent in sweet-meats to taste the Pallat, shall be now spent in sweet discourse to rellish the care.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p:
Fie, how long they stay, this houre is as long as three houres: I have observ'd one thing in Lovers houres, the time of
their absence seemes hugely too long, and the time when they are present is three to one too short.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And three to one is ods, but you are an old woman.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: That makes me long so much for a husband to make me even; what not yet come, nor yet? if they stay a little longer, I shall go neare to swoon thrice before they be ready to enter.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No entrance if you love me.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Yes at the private doore—

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Lady.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Imagine this night to be Saint Valentines day, when every bird chooseth her mate, for that is the season when they couple; I am here.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: And I here.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And I am glad, my Lord, that you are here; yet I would be loath, my Lord, have my Father know that you are so.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: That I am so seated, and you upon my knee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Upon my knees I beg that it may never come to his care.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Come, what shall's do?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Say what you will my Lord, but do nothing I entreat you.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: If we should do nothing, of that must necessary come ill, Ile prove it too; of doing nothing comes Idlenesse, of idlenesse comes no goodnesse, of no goodnesse necessary comes ill: therefore if we do nothing, of necessity we must do ill.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: How well, my Lord, you can infer ill; but, my Lord, if you should insist much in this argument, it were more to expresse your oratory than honesty; but my Lord, I know your vertues, and the opinion of them hath prepar'd you a most kind and loving welcome; we have nothing to entertaine you but words, and we can feast you with nothing but kisses; now you see your fare, fall to and welcome.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Madam, I could everlastingly feed here, and yet presume never to surfeit, I can but thanke you, and now I have given thankes, Ile even make bold to fall to.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You say you could find in your heart to offend my father.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: I madam, so for my offence he would everlastingly confine me to this prison; why smile you Lady?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: To thinke if my father should steale upon you, and find you here, what a cunning picklock he would take you for, he would questionlesse thinke you carried a false key about you.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Tush, he hath made a Jury of twelve doores already to pass upon my cause, and they have all given my case up not guilty—

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Where's the Dukes Guard?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Begirt the Castle round.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Her windows shine with lights like blazing stars.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Th'are in her Chamber sure.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Heard you that Madam?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We are betray'd.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: The Castle round beset.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: And harke, above I heare the Dukes keys, down the private way, and leave the excuse to us.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nay, when my Lords?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: This way my Lord, good night.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Nay, stand not now on triviall Complements,
The Duke's at hand.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Farewell, Ladies adieu.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nay, if you love us leave us; Madam, how shall we answer this to the Duke?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Now my apron strings if I had one on, Madam take your Chaire and counterfeit your selfe fast asleep, so will I, not a word now if you love me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Thy very words are better to me than a Physicall potion, for they have cast me into a sound sleep already; see I am fast—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Soft, make no noise, the Chamber's whist and still,
There's not so much aire stirring as would make
The trembling Aspen shake; ha, fast asleep?
Search round the Chamber.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I find no man here.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Here's naught but walls and Arras, and two Ladies
In depth of sleep.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Let's wake them my Lord and question them.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Not for thy head that hast deluded us,
And to this shame and mockery rais'd the Court,
Would I disturbe them of a minutes rest;
Thy envy unto such as we have rais'd
For their desert in Court hath stretch'd it selfe
Even to our high disturbance.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Hell and the furies,
Am I againe deluded?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Fie Lord Iulio,
To call us in a mockery from our beds!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Here to hunt shadows, sure the fellow dreamt.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Pray my Lord wake them, and resolve them how Lord Iulio hath possest you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Pardon me,
They both are charm'd in silence, and their senses
Confus'd in innocent dreames; I oft have heard
That what a man or woman waking thinks,
If they be question'd in their depth of rest
Their Genius or their soule will answer for them,
As their affections or their hearts inclin'd;
Of this Ile make a true and prosperous use,
And sound them how their humours are dispos'd,
And to my Daughter first, Lords stand apart,
How sweetly doth my Girle become her rest!
How sound are her suspires! Valentia.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: She answers me, now art thou happy Mantua,
For thou shalt sound the utmost of her thoughts;
Whom doth my Daughter most affect on earth?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I love none but my Father.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Oh mine own girle, and wouldst thou not have a husband?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ile live and dye a maid.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: There's no deceit in this, there's no dissembling,
Shee cannot study for evasive shifts,
I thanke heaven I am resolv'd: now Dutchess
Your turne is next, Ile try how she likes me,
What thinks the Dutchess of the Mantuan Duke?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: As of a fine grave noble Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Now she speakes her heart, this is plaine dealing;
And couldst thou be content to marry him?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: That's my desire.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And live his noble Dutchess.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I wish no better.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Mine own;
Most sweetly may you sleep, and nightly dreame
Of these positions, not for halfe my Dukedome
Would I disturbe their quiet; come let's leave them,
Nay pardon me, Ile see the Chamber cleer'd.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Could I be possibly thus mock'd?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Nay Gentlemen,
Ile be the Porter, see I keep the keyes
Of these two Jewels that I most esteeme;
Iulio, beware hereafter you incur not
Our wrath by these suggestions of untruths;
Come Lords to bed, I counsell you the best,
Goodnight my girles, and sweetly may you rest.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Are they gone wench?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I, and so gone that till they have slept soundly, 'tis not possible to fetch them againe.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Now Endymions fortune upon them, that being once asleep they may not wake againe this forty yeares.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Was it not well apprehended of me to say I lov'd none but my Father?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: And was it not as well seconded of me to say in my sleep I lov'd none but the Duke? Sure it must be in my sleep if ever I lov'd him, for yet I could never endure him waking; but what shall's do?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: By my counsell let us even go to bed like loving bedfellows, and see if we can dreame of them that in time may become our loving bedfellows.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p:
With all my heart, now the Duke is confident of our affections, we may be the freer in the entertaining of those whom we best affect; come, come, let's leave talking of this
counterfeit sleep, and see if we can take a nap in sadnesse.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: content, and let all men learne thus much from us, that sleeping or waking 'tis hard to o're-reach a woman. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Yet all things go currant; if the Ladies were as nimble in their excuse as we were quick in our passage through the private doore, I hope neither the Duke nor any of his Court can any way trace us in our proceedings; some Lovers would think me a most happy creature to enjoy the love of so beautiful a Lady, and for ought I know I may be so; but I have made a Vow never to marry a wife, but first to make some perfect and sound triall of her affection towards me; but because there is no woman that loves a man living, but she will infinitely lament him dead, it shall be thought that I have drown'd my selfe, of which I will give the Court some assured instance, and afterwards living hereabouts in some odd disguise, I shall truly understand how she takes my death; if in any extremity of griefe, I will revive her with as great a surplusage of joy; but if she take it coldly, as a business that little concernes her, Ile leave her to the mercy of him that bids fairest for her; and to my plot, I stay but for some company that may see me throw my selfe desperately into the River, heare my passion and report it—

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: My worke and every thing belonging to the Dukes building being brought to some good pass, I will study how to pass the time, and for the better recreation of my duller spirits take a turne or two here by the Rivers side to contemplate of the beauty of my Mistris; for indeed I am lately falne in love.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: No fitter man in the world to be the reporter of my death than this Coxcombe.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Upon a morning when I rose to breakfast like a glutton,
I don'd my doublet and my hose, and eate two legs of Mutton;
Her bonny looks forget I not, nor teeth as white as amber,
Her face did shine like pewter-pot belonging to the Chamber;
My lovely Mistris I espi'd as she a milking went a,
But oh me thought at every stride her smock that she had rent a;
Full pale she look'd, for on her head a milk-paile was well placed,
Her lips were white, her brows were red, her body was straitelaced;
But shall I now describe her legs, for I durst look no higher,
She went as if she trod on eggs most softly through the mire.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Now to my passion.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: But oh a place besides all these above both knees and thighs a,
Which spring, as she look'd for fleas, did make my stomack rise a.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Let Jove threat thunder, or bright Juno scold,
Mars threaten Armes, arm'd in Cyclopian steele,
He to my heels clap Boreas brazen wings,
Or mounted on the back of Mercury
With greater terrour scale the Olimpick heaven,
Then when the Giants muster'd here on earth,
And darted mountaine tops at Jupiter.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: What mad fellow's this? he hath driven me quite out of my meditations, pray heaven I fall not into his fegaries.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: But oh my beautious Dutchess, cause of this
My frenzy, lunacy, rage, and despaire,
I love thee dearely; yet because my fervor
Shall no way cross the noble Mantuan Duke,
I am resolv'd to dye.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Of all the trades that are I love not this dying, poore Gentleman, would the Duke knew as much; but if love put a man into these perplexities, Ile take heed how I meddle with it, Ile e'ne shake hands with it, and part with it as it came.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Whom do I see, the Duke of Mantua's Joy,
She whose bright beauty enamours Jove himselfe,
And makes him from his chrystall throne descend
To 'bide with this faire mortal, thou art she.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Not I I assure you, I am a man and no woman, if you will not beleeve me, I have a warrant about me to shew.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Come, thou art she, wilt thou dissemble love?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I am not she, looke here I have a beard.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: 'Tis but the perriwig falne from thy temples,
And staies upon thy Chin, thou art my Dutchess;
But stay, Ile place this border right againe,
And set it on thy front where it should stand.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Oh sir, Ile bring the Dukes own barber that shall take
his oath upon a corporall book, that this is a beard and no perriwig; I am he that was overseer of the Dukes worke, and not the faire Dutchess that you take me for, put on your spectacles, and you will see I am nothing like her.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Then she is lost, and I undone withall,
Therefore Ile strip me to the Ivory skin,
And as Leander did lively leape in,
My head beneath yon River I will run,
Neptune spread wide thy armes, for now I come. Exit running.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Oh save the man, save the man, now he flounces, now he flounders, yet he swims above water like a walnut shell, yet he sprawles like a naked frog, yet he strives for life, oh save the man, save the man; but now, now, now he sinkes by degrees, now he is swallow'd, now he is choak'd, this is my comfort, he cannot choose but go with a cleane soule to heaven, it will be so wash'd in the water before he come thither. Againe, againe, againe; now he lies still upon his back and floates along with the tide, and now his soule is in the skies, he doth not offer so much as to strive against the streame, but swims as gently down with the tide as may be; but what a foole was he, that knowing he should go so long a journey by water, and the weather so could too, would leave his cloaths behind him? Well, Ile e'ne take up his scatter'd Apparell, carry them to the Court, and there report what I have heard and seen, the poore Gentleman is well onward of his journey by this time, they had need provide him good store of faggots, for hee'l be monstrously wet when he comes to his Inne.

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Mantua, Florence, Ferrara, Iulio, Prospero, and Dutchesse.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: LAdy, I understand and good tidings from you.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: From me my Lord?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'Tis all one Madam, you at length are wonne
Unto a second marriage.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Hath Montecelso then told to the Duke
Of my free grant and yeelding to his love?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Sir, I must have you freely reconcil'd
To the Lord Iulio that hath put upon you
Such slanderous imputations.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: You my Lord
Can much with me, but were't for the reverence
I owe your Grace my sword had character'd
My wrong upon his body.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Come, all friends.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: My Lord, I yeeld my selfe, and here confess
In what high measure I have injur'd you.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: That's too much to receive injury and make satisfaction too.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: He slandered you most vilely.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Told the Duke
You were safe lodg'd within Valentia's Tower.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Made us to girt the place with the Dukes Guard.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: And at the high'st of night search all her Lodgings
For you and th' Architector.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: But who found you?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: None but two sleeping Ladies, and they fast
Surpriz'd in innocent dreames.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Was this wrong
To be endur'd?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Where the guilt's confest
There pardon is soone purchast.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Ile not beleeve
But there's in this some jugling, some strange feat—

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Roome for a bringer of ill news, for one that brings a tale will offend all your noses, and a discourse that will distaste all your eares; who knows this Hat? who knows this Doublet? who knows this Cloake?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: These were Lord Montecelso's; why my heart Art thou struck cold with feare?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: These were my friends.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: If I mistake not these belong'd to him
Whom I preferr'd to over-see my works,
What news of him?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: You that lov'd him, out with your eyes, and wipe your handkerchers, and as you look upon this Cloake provide for a shower of raine.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Speake, what of him?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: He is dead, he is fled, he is not wounded, but he is drowned, he is gone for ever, for he is leapt into the River.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Dead!

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Drown'd!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: How came he drown'd? speake.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Marry with water, belike it got into his mouth and choak'd him.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: There's one gone yet.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I meane discourse the cause that urg'd him to't.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
As I was walking by the Rivers side, musing and meditating on some passions incident to men of my complexion, I spi'd this Gentleman starke staring mad, exclaiming on the beauty of this faire Dutchess, saying, that he run mad for her love; but because he would not be false to the Duke his Master, that put him in trust, he would rather shew himselfe to be no better than a drown'd Rat than deceive him, and so very courteously
casts away his Hat, very dolefully laies by his Cloake, very dissolutely hurles off his Doublet, very desperately leaps into the River, and very dangerously gives up the Ghost.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: It drives me to amazement,
And I am wrapt in wonder.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Oh my Fate!
I am of all the most unfortunate;
Ile not out-live him.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Wherefore doth my Dutchesse
Shew in her looks such sad distemperature?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I am lost, there steales a coldnesse through my bloud,
The Icy hand of death plaies on my breasts,
And where it toucheth turneth all to earth,
And I am doom'd—

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Look to the Lady, see she faints.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How cheare you Lady?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Ha, am I call'd againe?
Then like a soule disturb'd in her departure,
And kept from rest and downie quietnesse,
Let me proclaime my anguish.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Patience Lady.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Ile not be patient, give me leave to drowne
My soule in brine, and in a floud of teares
Swim to my Love.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: The Dutchess is distracted.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I am so, I am desperate, frantick, mad,
Go call yon Architector from the deeps,
And he shall build a Castle in the aire,
Where we will live together 'midst the Clouds
And laugh at these poore mortals here on earth.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: The Ladie's mad.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: You are deceiv'd, not I;
Cannot a Lady weepe, mourne, or lament,
Or spend a few teares o're a funerall hearse
But you will judge her frantique, pray give leave,
Which of you here can hinder me to weep?
I am a woman

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I am a man.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Women command teares,
Then pray let me bestow some on a friend;
If you will dye go hang or drowne your selves,
Ile do the like for you.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Yes, not for me.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Why should I weepe for thee if thou didst so,
Or thee, or thee, or any dotard here,
Yet if you please you may go try for me,
He clap at that well-acted Tragedy.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Oh save the woman, save the woman.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Follow her Iulio, see her well attended;
Sure she is Planet-struck, or some ill star
Hath in her bosome wrought this mutinous war,

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Ile see well to her safety.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Oh my Dutchesse!

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: These are but womens passions,
And like a tempest, the more violent 'tis
'Twill be the sooner blown o'r.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: So I hope.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Feare not my Lord, perhaps she counterfeits
To know how you affect her, if in this
You will compassionate with her, and partake
In this supposed frenzie.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'Tis like so,
For if a man may trust a sleeping woman,
She loves me 'bove the world.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: My Lord I know it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Nay, I know it too, Ile never else trust dreames.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: But leaving this, I have a sute unto your Grace.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Speake and prevaile deare friend.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: There is a Spanish Lady my first Love,
Who heating of my residence with you,
Is travell'd thence to meet me in your Court,
I have notice that she shortly will arive;
My purpose is to feast her in my Lodging
So lately built, next to your Daughters Tower,
Where if it please you with these Lords to grace me,
And taste a homely banquet, I shall say
To you I am engaged every way.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I will not faile thee, nor shall these our friends,
Wee'l grace the Spanish Lady with our presence.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I have a sute to your Grace.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Thy business Groome?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: That for the good news I have brought you I may have some guerdon, some remuneration, as they say.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: This thy reward be, since by thy occasion
My Dutchess of her best wits is depriv'd,
Wander for ever like a banish'd Caine,
Till of her sence she be possest againe
Dare not so neare our Court. Come Lords, let's in
To cheere her sorrows, and her fate lament,
But to the man that can her frenzie cure
We here proclaime what e're he can demand,
If in the compasse of our populous Land.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Banish, what's that? can any man tell me what it means? let me see; Banish'd sure is some strange language, and for any thing I know the meaning of it may be, give him a hundred Crowns, or give him two hundred Crowns; and banish'd the Court may be come to the Court and there you shall receive them; the Duke was not wont to give me such hard words; if he had call'd me Rogue or Rascall, I had understood him, I had had him to a haire, but the word banish'd doth a little stick in my stomack; Banish'd! I will go seek out some wise man or other to tell me what the the word meanes, and what sum of money, I may demand of the Dukes Treasurer; Banish'd—

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Save you sir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: And you my friend, what are you?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Sir I professe my selfe to be a wise man.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Then you are the man that I desire to meet, for I was seeking a wise man to tell me the meaning of a strange word.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Unfold thy mind; I shall resolve thee truly
Lye it within the power of humane skill.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Thus Stands the case: The Duke entertain'd a fellow to looke to his buildings, and this fellow drown'd himselfe, it was my fate to bring the news to the Court, which when the young
